info.name: vRealize Operations REST API Examples
info.description:
**Description**

A collection of vRealize Operations REST APIs organized by use case.  This collection is updated frequently and typically using the latest release of vRealize Operations.

Also now include are some examples for deploying a new vRealize Operations cluster using the CASA API.  CASA stands for Cluster and Slice Administration.  This API allows you to install and manage your cluster. 

Authorization for the REST APIs are handled via OAuth and an API call is included that will request and store a token for the other REST calls.  Be sure to set the included variables for your env.  Basic auth is only used by the REST API "Run First" call.

Authentication for CASA uses basic and you will also need to get the master node thumbprint for some of these workflows.

Also, many of the REST calls have tests, which store additional information as part of a workflow.  Be sure to set headers to send/rec payloads in JSON format, as the tests assume this format.  Default for vROps API is XML so any post-tests will fail and any pre-tests provide env vars in JSON format.

**Documentation**

Documentation for the APIs can be found on the vROps appliance:

/suite-api for the REST APIs
/casa/api-guide.html for the CASA REST APIs

**Contributors:**

John Dias, diasj@vmware.com
Chris McClanahan, mcclanahanc@vmware.com
Brandon Gordon, gbrandon@vmware.com

item.name: Create an EPOPS Windows Service Monitor Resource
Create an EPOPS Unix MultiProcess Monitor Resource
Add Child Resource to a Resource

request.description:
This operation adds a child resource to a resource.  

API documentation states that POST is additive while PUT is destructive (i.e. overwites existing relationships).

JSON body includes an array of child objects to add.  

The call does not provide a lot of detail for failure, but it seems
that if you have an invalid UUID for a child or the child is already related
then it will fail with 400.

204 is a successful call.
Gets all - to get a single report ID, just add /<report def id>

You will need to update several items in the body such as:
  - ID of resource you wish to run this report on
  - ID of the report you wish to run
  - Traversal Spec for the report (you can get this from the API query
"Get Report Definitions", the travesal spec must match the resource type.

You can check status of report runs this way.
To get a specific generated report add /<report id>

item.name: Get An Adapter Instance(s) of Type (Kind)

request.description:
Be sure to check values in the JSON body for credentials.
Also note you will need to start the adapter using "Star an adapter instance" 
after creation using the UUID from the response.

If you aren't using a CA, the certificate will have to be added via the UI
I do not know of a way to do this via the REST API

Be sure to check values in the JSON body for credentials.
Also note you will need to start the adapter using "Star an adapter instance" 
after creation using the UUID from the response.

If you aren't using a CA, the certificate will have to be added via the UI
I do not know of a way to do this via the REST API

Replace the UUID with the ID of the adapter instance you want to start
This can be retrieved using Get Adapter Instances

item.name: Get Virtual Machine by Resource Identifier

request.description: I have not tested but you may be able to use the "resourceIds" input paramter to specify multiple resources (of the same kind, obviously).  The example here shows a daily avg for 30 days.  Timestamps are milli from epoch.

request.description:

You can then use this within the body of a request

item.name: Get StatKeys for Resource and Load var

request.description:
Grabs CPU statKeys for a VM resource using the {{resourceId}} env var.
Populates two env vars:
cpuStatKeys for GET stats for small requests (1 to ~10 VMs)
cpuStatKeysJSON for POST stats for large requests (use in conjunction with {{resourceIds}}

item.name: Add or Update Stats of a Resource

body.raw:
{
  "compositeOperator" : "AND",
  "symptomId" : [ ],
  "resource-query" : {
    "name" : null,
    "regex" : null,
    "adapterKind" : null,
    "resourceKind" : null,
    "collectorName" : null,
    "collectorId" : null,
    "maintenanceScheduleId" : null,
    "adapterInstanceId" : null,
    "recentlyAdded" : null,
    "resourceState" : null,
    "resourceStatus" : null,
    "resourceHealth" : null,
    "parentId" : null,
    "credentialId" : null,
    "resourceId" : [ "5748438c-41d5-4397-a59b-efe973674653" ],
    "propertyName" : null,
    "propertyValue" : null,
    "statKey" : null,
    "statKeyLowerBound" : null,
    "statKeyUpperBound" : null,
    "statKeyInclusive" : true,
    "others" : [ ],
    "otherAttributes" : {
    }
  },
  "includeChildrenResources" : false,
  "activeOnly" : true,
  "alarmType" : [ ],
  "alarmCriticality" : [ "CRITICAL", "IMMEDIATE", "WARNING", "INFORMATION" ],
  "symptomDefinitionId" : [ ],
  "statKey" : [ ],
  "others" : [ ],
  "otherAttributes" : {
  }
}

request.description: Example that uses "Get Resources by resourceKind and Load var" to provide a list of resource IDs using the {{resourceId}} env var.

header.warning: This is a duplicate header and will be overridden by the Authorization header generated by Postman.

request.description: Example that uses "Get Resources by resourceKind and Load var" to provide a list of resource IDs using the {{resourceId}} env var.
May also include query such as id, roleName and username

Be sure to check values in the JSON body for credentials.
Also note you will need to start the adapter using "Star an adapter instance" 
after creation using the UUID from the response.

If you aren't using a CA, the certificate will have to be added via the UI
I do not know of a way to do this via the REST API

Replace the UUID with the ID of the adapter instance you want to start
This can be retrieved using Get Adapter Instances

item.name: Apply License Key to Weekly vROps

request.description:
Be sure to check values in the JSON body for credentials.
Also note you will need to start the adapter using "Star an adapter instance" 
after creation using the UUID from the response.

If you aren't using a CA, the certificate will have to be added via the UI
I do not know of a way to do this via the REST API

You will need to have populated 

* resourceId env var
* actionId env var

Response is parsed and saved as input for the performAction API
Run Populate Action first get body - copy and paste the "action-execution" value in the body of this request.  Update values in body as desired.
For an action that has been run, you can use this to check status.  actionExecutionId is pre-populated from the Perform Action request.
